Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: A novel approach to STEM education through a personalized mobile cooking app for K-8 students
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase II project deals with the development of a gamified educational platform meant to excite and inspire children to learn about the sciences through the medium of cooking. By engaging students with interactive content in K-8 classrooms, after school programs, and special education settings, the proposed innovation aims to simultaneously accomplish three outcomes that are important to K-8 students' education and healthy living. These outcomes include: (1) helping students develop a highly practical skill (cooking), (2) generating excitement about and enhancing learning in several scientific disciplines (particularly nutrition science, STEM, and human geography), and (3) promoting a highly desirable behavior in students (the development of healthy eating habits). This project proposes to develop a prototype version of the innovative educational technology. It builds upon an existing proof-of-concept application that integrates nutrition science (in the form of cooking recipes) with human geography (different countries and cultures) and significantly enhances this application by innovatively linking the cooking-related content to a STEM curriculum and testing the addition of a variety of capabilities meant to increase user engagement and learning through the application. This Phase I proposal will research the feasibility and usability of the product, and investigate the extent to which the proposed technology is able to simultaneously achieve the three stated outcomes in a way that outperforms traditional paper-based school curricula. With the market for mobile learning products valued at $12.2 billion, the company's three-pronged approach to improving learning and health-related outcomes for K-8 students stands to generate significant revenue. The team estimates that the business can reach roughly 2 million in sales in the first three years following the product?s launch.

The proposed research will explore (1) various ways for the system to automatically link cooking concepts with STEM concepts in a way that enhances learning and engagement and produces a curriculum compliant with Next Generation Science Standards, (2) the application of emotional intelligence to data gathered, such that the technology will track students? mood and food choices, and provide suggestions based on an optimal match between the two, and (3) the use of adaptive learning to effectively deliver the above curriculum in a targeted and personalized manner (including accommodations for children with special needs during Phase II). These outcomes will be achieved by creating and testing new capabilities for the system, including the ability to monitor user performance, a points-based progression system, personalization, customized STEM games, and matching students with recipes and lesson plans based on their culinary preferences and emotional moods, the majority of which will be implemented via the use of machine learning. Overall, the goal of the small business is to develop several different app features that incorporate the above-mentioned approaches, and to determine, through repeated and rigorous classroom testing with K-8 students, which combination of features maximizes the learning and behavioral outcomes that the application is targeting.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chef Koochooloo aims to tackle both the failure in STEM and the obesity crisis children in the US face today. We plan to improve the health, education and happiness of children globally by creating an international education platform that teaches K-6 students cultural diversity, science, and math through healthy cooking.

Nutrition education in elementary schools plays an important role in shaping students' food choices, overall health, and academic performance (Contento, 1995; O'Dea, 2012; Anzman-Frasca, 2015). Most states require that elementary-aged students receive some form of nutritional education; however, dietary behavior and nutrition do not receive the attention needed to achieve long-term effects on student attitude and behavior (Department of Education, 2012; Perera, 2015). Nutritional education suffers from a disconnect between its learning outcomes, the amount of time and academic priority given to implementing successful nutrition interventions, and the food environment to which students are exposed; this causes students to question the validity and importance of the messages learned in the classroom, thus making it more difficult to develop healthy dietary behaviors (Shepherd et al., 2005; Bauer et al., 2006; Perera, 2015).

To this end, Chef Koochooloo   is developing a gamified educational platform for use by K-6 students, their teachers and parents. The application allows users to learn and cook recipes in a fun and interactive way, while also learning about various topics--including STEAM (mainly science & math), nutrition, and global competence--which are delivered via a curriculum compliant with Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). Users interact with the app and can search for recipes based on various preferences such as a ingredient, diet, country, etc. Along the way, they encounter facts related to a recipe, such as benefits of an ingredient in the recipe, information about a country of origin, math in measurements of ingredients, etc. The application combines gamification features to increase user engagement with personalized, adaptive learning and with a Machine Learning-based system for determining students' latent food proclivities, with the goal of enhancing their learning experience and engagement with the app. By engaging students with carefully developed interactive content, the project aims to simultaneously develop a highly practical and useful life skill (healthy cooking), create excitement about learning, and enhance student proficiency in STEAM (mainly science & math) and English Language Arts/Development ELA (through concepts related to nutrition and global competence) when compared to a traditional school curriculum,

In Phase I, we developed a minimum viable product, and tested its effectiveness via a pilot study to evaluate promise, which was conducted across 11 schools in California. A total of 259 K-3 students  participated in this study; 159 were in the treatment group (i.e., were enrolled in and completed the pilot study), and 109 were in the control group (i.e., were not enrolled in the pilot study). Students enrolled in the pilot attended a cooking & STEAM class taught by Chef Koochooloo instructors once a week for 10 consecutive weeks. Students in the control group did not receive any cooking- or STEAM-related education outside of the regular class curriculum. Students in both groups used the Chef Koochooloo application to complete a short test that assessed their STEAM and English Language Arts/English Language Development (ELA/ELD) knowledge at two points in time: before the pilot study (i.e., pre-test) and after the duration of the pilot study (i.e., post-test). The test consisted of a series of multiple-choice questions focused around ELA/ELD (using concepts related to nutrition and global competency) and  STEAM topics, and based on the curriculum taught in the Chef Koochooloo class.

A comparison of the pre- to the post-test results showed that the control group saw was only a very slight increase in ELA/ELD scores (13%), and no increase in STEAM scores (3%). In contrast, the pilot group saw a statistically significant and relatively large improvement in both ELA/ELD (55%) and STEAM scores (51%), which occurred both in in-school and after-school settings.
By developing and testing an MVP of the Chef Koochooloo application, we have shown that the use of an interactive game-based educational technology application in various school setting has the potential to positively impact K-2 students' learning outcomes in STEAM and ELA/ELD. There is also some preliminary evidence collection from teachers for a positive impact on student's understanding of Nutrition and cooking. Hence, the Chef Koochooloo application shows great promise as an educational tool that is fun, engaging, and effective, while providing an innovative way for students to interact with and assimilate knowledge.

Already empowering over 2,000 educators and parents worldwide through our pilot programs and after school enrichment programs, Chef Koochooloo envisions to improve the education and eating habits of children everywhere, creating healthier, happier children who are socially responsible and aware of the world they live in.
